description: This two-semester second-level writing course aims to guide students to (1) practice basic academic writing convention, (2) sharpen analytical essay writing skills, (3) enhance essay coherence and cohesion, and (4) develop a clear writing style. The course will familiarize students with proper academic language and convention to compose five-paragraph short essays on the following five modes of writing: argumentation, definition, causal analysis, process analysis, and comparison and contrast. In addition to the different analytical modes of writing, the course will introduce students to organizing and editing strategies to fine-tune their essay writing. On the one hand, students will learn how to apply principles of coherence and cohesion in their writing to maintain consistent claims and to offer logical transitions at the levels of ideas, sentences, and paragraphs. On the other hand, students will learn how to develop a clear writing style by avoiding common sentence errors and improving concision and specificity in word choice and sentence formation.
goals: 1.　To help students student develop their ability to express themselves in writing essays in English
2.　To help students write various kinds of essays in a well-organized manner

*   **Course Description:**

Intermediate Writing (II) aims to develop students’ writing skills and critical thinking through systematic writing practice. It will provide students with opportunities to write in different modes of discourse. Course time will be devoted largely to discussions of the structural components of academic essays, writing samples, common writing errors, and rhetoric strategies. In addition to lectures, this course will engage students in various writing activities, such as group discussion, peer review and editing.

*   **Course Objectives:**

At the end of this course, students will be able to

1.  identify the structural components of expository writing;
2.  employ different rhetoric strategies for various purposes in writing;
3.  articulate how audience expectation and writing purposes shape writing products;
4.  diagnose and edit their own essays.

*   **Delivery of instruction:**

1.  Lecture
2.  Group discussion & cooperation
3.  Peer review & editing
4.  Student presentation

*   **Grading Policy & Course Requirements:**

**1.     Grading Policy:**

    (1) Attendance/participation: 20%

    (2) Essays and revisions: 45%

    (3) Peer review/feedback: 10%

    (4) Reading responses: 25%

**2\. Reading Responses (25%)**

Students have to hand in five reading reflective reports (single-spacing, 1-inch on all margins) in this semester, and each report is at least one full page. Reading materials will be provided by the instructor and students have to reflect upon what they have learned from the articles.

**3\. Classroom Policies:**

(1) Class attendance is a fundamental requirement that will be strictly enforced in this course. Students are required to come to class every week. Absence from **each class period** will result in a 2-point deduction from students’ attendance/participation score (except for a valid excuse approved by the instructor). Arriving late to class or leaving early will also count as an absence. Students’ participation will also be scored based on how much they contribute to discussions.

(2) Please participate in group discussions (e.g., group work, peer review, etc.) in English.

(3) Students are required to submit any of their assignments (including reports and projects) before it is due. Late assignments will be marked down by **30%**. Once they are two or more days late, they will NOT be accepted under any circumstances. 

(4) Dishonesty: Academic dishonesty is a misconduct that occurs in academic exercises. It involves plagiarism, cheating, fabrication, etc. Students will be penalized for academic dishonesty on any tests, assignments and exercises.

**4\. Textbook:**

(1) There is no set textbook for this course. Reading materials will be provided.

(2) Recommended materials:

(a) Wyrick, J. (2014). _Steps to writing well_ (12th ed.). MA: Wadsworth.

(b) Carlock, J., Eberhardt, M., Horst, J., & Menasche, L. (2010). _The ESL writer’s handbook_. Michigan: The University of Michigan Press.

(c) Skwire, S. E., & Skwire, D. (2011). _Writing with a thesis: A rhetoric and reader_ (11thed.). MA: Wadsworth.

(d) Free online lecture videos on Coursera: [https://www.coursera.org/](https://www.coursera.org/)

   (We will discuss several free lectures on Coursera. You can register on it and enroll in courses for free. Choose “Audit Only” and you can read course materials and watch lecture videos provided by the instructor.)
